data.text: How easy is It to Find Warmshower Hosts in Europe?
Hi, have you used Warmshower system when bike touring in Europe? The membership fee is 30 euro, so I am thinking is it worth of that. How easy is it to find a host? Thanks!
Easy to find hosts, using the map on the app.

data.text: Just toured across Europe. Plenty of warmshowers options and almost always had a response. 30 euros once and that one night at a hotel or three at a hostel. Worth it.

data.text: That's like saying McDonald's is really good, you have to pay, but you get some calories and fat and god knows what; better than nothing, right? Warmshowers (and Couchsurfing) used to be a LOT better before they started screwing it up with the profit and compulsive growth mentality.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: First time I hear about the $30 fee for new accounts. That is pretty bad! I know they have been screwing up our network for years already, just like couchsurfing... Different from couchsurfing existing Warmshowers members don't have to pay, we can contribute voluntarily though. Also different from couchsurfing, it is certainly worth using Warmshowers even if you have to pay the $30 (which like wrote is only once in a lifetime), because it will pay back easily in multiple ways. You will meet a lot a great people, fellow cyclists.
data.author: Martin Koole

data.text: The new fee is a shame. Same with Couchsurfing. I can‚Äôt even log into my Couchsurfing account because they require I pay a ‚Äúvoluntary donation‚Äù to get past the paywall. So all my Couchsurfing request have gone unanswered for over a year now.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: Yes, it is. It is hopelessly against how the majority wants it to be. It's worth looking for alternatives to go back to how it all started: a free platform for people with a free mind in a free world.

data.text: I think Covid has a lot to do with the decline of Warmshowers, but unfortunately also the fact that they have seemingly taken the route that Couchsurfing took. I warmed about this when all that talk started about making it more "efficient", building new apps, creating merchandise, etc, etc. I said, it works fine on a limited budget per year but no, as USA mentality dictates, growth, growth, growth (and then eventually profit, profit). It's sad but eventually a new "Warmshowers" and a new "Couchsurfing" etc, will have to be invented because greed or ambition, etc, don't let what's not broke go without "fixing."
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: hello, maybe also try the free MakeYourTripBetter website to put you directly in touch with locals or recent travelers with a profile similar to yours. they will certainly have very good advice.
data.author: Olivier Gibouin

data.text: Some of the comments are just silly. Warmshowers is not commercial! It is a non-profit organization that is charging a very modest fee (about the cost of one night in a campground) to cover the costs of offering a great networking service to long-distance cyclists because not enough members were donating voluntarily. I've stayed with many amazing Warmshowers hosts in Europe and the US, and have hosted several delightful cyclists at my home in Florida. My experience in Europe was generally very positive. However, you can expect a very low response rate from hosts directly on the more popular EV routes during the peak summer months. This is to be expected - one host told me he received nearly 100 requests a weak during the summer. Once you get slightly off the beaten path I found the positive response rate to be very high.
data.author: Todd Burgman

data.text: thank you! The 30‚Ç¨ will probably be repaid in the kindness of one night.
data.author: Jeffrey Mcelfresh

data.text: Absolutely worth it. We had a wonderful host take us in at 10 pm at night in Bourdeaux when all the hotels were full.
data.author: Derek Heffernan

data.text: I sent money several times to Couchsurfing and Warmshowers when they relied on voluntary donations. Couchsurfing was getting millions but squandered it, then betrayed the community by going for-profit. Warmshowers was working well with the simple format and a modest budget, but the business obsessed people had to inject their "entrepreneurial" ambitious culture and, as feared and predicted, are now charging compulsory fees. No knowing where they will stop. They lost my trust.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: We have stayed at warmshowers many times. We hosted more people than staying. It's a great concept. But a free service is useless. Any thing free will find it difficult to keep it up and improve. It does not help we have hosts and guests but no infrastructure to keep it together. Pay the ‚Ç¨30 and get involved to make it better. Don't just use it. üëç

data.text: As said worth it. But talking about responses- not all over Europe is the same. Hosts in popular, attractive locations get many questions, hard to get response for example in Italy.

data.text: I had the same issues. The app won't let you see where the host are until you sign up. I took the plunge and it worked out fine there are lots of hosts I'm sure you'll find some too.
data.author: David Chili Cheesefries Cornell

data.text: Warmshowers works when the members respect the philosophy of the site. Biking across Spain and France last fall I sent out 44 requests for a place to stay. I got back only 14 responses, most of the responses were that they had either moved or weren‚Äôt taking in guests. Those people should make themselves unavailable on the site. My last night in France I was accepted by a family. It was glorious. Now I‚Äôm going back and biking with the host who will be my friend forever! That‚Äôs what warmshowers should be!
data.author: Hall Hitzig

data.text: I‚Äôve used it a few times and so far it‚Äôs been great! Just make sure to only contact hosts who have been active in the last 2 weeks (ish), (it says on their profile). That way you can avoid having less responses from people who haven‚Äôt logged in in ages üôÇ
data.author: Alex Sidney

data.text: We joined it a couple of months ago for south America. We didn't use it too much but others we met had and did pretty well with responses. We ended up using it a few times to just meet up with local bikers and have made a few fantastic friends from it. No regrets about joining up.

data.author: Steve Lindley
Kate Rhodes

data.text: I have been a member of Warmshowers for over 18 years, and used it as a guest and host many, many times. It has grown to be so big that the site needs the small fee to run it properly. It is one of the best parts of bike touring. I encourage everyone to not only pay the fee but to donate more if you can. Many of my best memories of bike tours are the wonderful hosts with whom we have stayed. One tip I give to new users is to send requests to hosts who have a high response rate, which is listed on their profile. And do be sure to read the whole profile. Some of us are on extremely busy routes and get lots of requests, so we may have a hint within the profile for a guest to include in their request in order for us to accept them. Also read the feedback, and be sure to leave one of your own after your stay.
data.author: Marti Fine

data.text: There is no fee. Somebody's trying a rip off
data.author: Gonzo Geierschnabel
